description:
I've been using LibreOffice as my main office package for many years now (since Sun's StarOffice some 19 years ago), succesfully preparing professional documents, presentation and training courses counting hundreds of slides. Usability improves with every single version and I find it actually more intuitive and easy to use than MS Office. The interoperability with the latter has gone a long way through to reach a very reasonable level as of present. It is certainly a viable free alternative for all educational uses, as well as for many professional ones.
Formatting of default templates are not my favourite (non-optimal use of slide space, for my taste), yet it is so much easy to craft a template that fits your needs and use it by default.
Contrary to other opinions quoted here, I haven't encounter any major crash for a long time now, even though I use it quite routinely - it is like that since many versions of Fedora, actually.

This app is serviceable. Make sure that you save often, as it's unstable. I recommend only using this program for quick edits, as anything heavier than inserting text will most likely crash the program.

I generally feel like the LibreOffice tools are functionally on-par with their Microsoft or Google equivalents, but my experience with Impress has been absolutely awful. Besides the fact that I'm constantly fighting with bugs, such as text boxes that deselect themselves each time I type a character in them, the customization is incredibly tedious and obscure. I had to go to google just to figure out how to change the font in text boxes.

It's compatible with MS PowerPoint, which is good if the majority of your peers/ colleagues use Windows/ MacOS and are rich enough to buy MS office, but upon attempting to save a particularly large powerpoint [about 390 MB], in LibreOffice Impress, It froze everything on my computer, took up about 6 GB of my 8 GB RAM, despite the document in question only being a fraction of that. It then crashed, making me have to open LibreOffice again and attempt to recover it. In total, I had to attempt to recover it more than 5 times, possibly about 10 times, as it was important coursework that I needed to complete
After that it *F I N A L L Y* saved. 
I feel like migrating to a different office software because of this.
In case you're wondering, I'm using Ubuntu 20.04 LTS, and judging by the look of the new branding, it'll take a while for me to upgrade to 22.04
I love it! there are so many details design that impressed me, sometimes even better than Apple Keynote.
